ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I changed my status to an auditor bc I lost interest in the course material.
I wish that the professor made it clear that the field trip was optional. Considering that several of the speakers at the field trip conference had already spoken for the class it felt pointless.

The class meetings (1 hour) were quite brief, and topics were fairly disparate. I think the course wouldbe strengthened by taking a step back to look at the big picture, and how the different lecture topics connect to each other.
I did not attend the field trip.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The variety of constituents' views addresses and speakers presented to us on a weekly basis.
Liked the mix of professionals and land use planning projects in the northeast. Also appreciated the effort to set up dinners after the lecture for interested students.
Get exposure to different professionals from all aspects of the planning field.
Visiting lecturers offered lots of different perspectives on the topic, which I loved. Also, there seemed to be an arc to the course, which I appreciated.
The Q&A following each presentation. And the instructor expertise.
The last lecture's focus on the challenges of Hurricane Sandy and sea level rise were very relevant and a good way to connect and summarize all of the speakers.
inspiring lectures
Hearing from various (although very similar) professionals in the field.
I found some of the lectures, like Marjorie Shanksy's, to be fantastic and wished we had more time on those days.
I like the collaborative decision making and place making speakers.
Breadth, interesting speakers, great variety.

Opportunity to meet and network with practitioners in the land use planning field. The after-class dinners with speakers are a wonderful opportunity for students to engage. John Nolon is obviously very interested and committed to the professional development of his students (perhaps more so than many of the academic-y professors at FES). He goes out of his way to give students the opportunity to meet mentors, suggest internship opportunities, and engage with the LUCY SIG; this is very much appreciated! Nolon is also very perceptive and open to adapting the class to the changing needs and interests of the students, and he is quite proactive in soliciting feedback.
The speakers had a wide-range of skill sets that were interesting.
the plethora of practitioners who came to talk to us
Some guest speakers were very interesting, such as Meg Walker and the people from Newburgh.
The wide variety of speakers, particularly Professor Shansky, and the Project for Public Spaces.
The range of speakers and the interesting topics were great and can inform what other topics you may want to pursue while at FES.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The trip to Pace Law School was originally listed as mandatory, but very few of the students ultimately ended up attending. The law conference was at a point in the semester when most of us had heavy workloads, and it was difficult to set aside the time. I appreciated the effort to bring everyone to the conference, but didn't find the experience as useful as I would have liked because we had already heard many similar presentations throughout the semester from the same speakers.

More class time to get into material and ask questions of the speakers. Perhaps additional assignments and interactive presentation formats to engage more on the readings and substance.More diversity in terms of speakers.

Provide more opportunities for discussion - Q&A with speakers was good, but sometimes short (and often didn't fit into the 4-5 pm time slot). Also, would have liked to hear more from classmates about their backgrounds, experience, and interests.

It would be better to have more of an introduction from the professor at the beginning of the course, for example by examining a case study. I didn't feel like I got a good foundation of land use planning, but just some different perspectives on frameworks. I also walked away feeling very overwhelmed, because the field just seems like a breeding ground for polarizing discussion, and not a solution to environmental problems. One way to fix this would be to have a theme each semester. This semester's theme could have been sea level rise, which would have been very relevant in light of the severe hurricane season.
Alternate guest speakers with traditional lecture / discussion - many of the speakers were repetitive.
Other days, I got little out of the lectures because of the lecturer's style or not being as interested in that topic.
Several of the speakers were not interesting or valuable. I think the class should prioritize interesting speakers.

A). Perhaps include a greater proportion of speakers from the private sector land development sector. Maybe even include a typical strip mall/residential subdivision type of developer to provide a different perspective to the class so they could understand the perspectives, regulations, and incentives (for better or worse) that promote this type of land development. B). The changing real estate market (trend towards more urban living/less sprawl) is fascinating. We touched on this in the last class this semester, and it would be interesting to hear more on this trend as it continues to develop.
More interaction and engaging students with speakers.
the readings
Some more overall structure would help students get more out of each speaker.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: yes it was

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am an Archaeological Studies MA candidate. As a result, I have a requirement to take one class in F&ES. I selected this class, and am thrilled I did, because of the large number of speakers who presented to us and the expanse covered by the material on the topic of Land Use Planning.
This course complements other land use planning courses that I am taking at FES.
This course fits in with my work with urban areas and intersection of law and land use decision-making.
Exploring land use planning as a potential future career. This course was only minimally helpful.
it helps me to understand the basic framework of land use planning and lays a good foundation for my concentration
The course is very specific about land use law in the Conn / NY area.
I do policy, and land use and planning have always been something I was interested in.
I am interested in land use planning as a career. I think I could have learned so much more from the class.

Part of the land use planning concentration at FES. Although, I have a background working with land use planning issues, this course was valuable in learning the similarities/differences in local land use planning in the Northeast versus the region where I previously worked. I also gained more insight into the legal and private development side of land development and conservation.
This course was not part of my core curriculum as an MF but I found it to be a great survey of land use issues and a good change of pace from other courses I took this semester.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: This course interested me the most in F&ES, given the field is new to me.

I am studying land use planning but do not have much background experience. I took this course to gain insight into different professions related to planning and to gain an understanding of current projects.
To expand knowledge and gain exposure from practioners in urban and land use planning.
To begin learning about Land Use issues.

I am interested in Industrial Ecology, specifically environmental business operations and changes to the industrial food system. Land use seemed very relevant for planning food landscapes and waste management.
To learn the basics of land use planning.
interested in land use planning and landscape architecture
I thought it would be more general about land use, but instead it was very specific about law, local level planning, and about the Conn / NY area.
See previous
I am interested in land use planning as a career.
I wanted an introduction to land use issues.
It was a good overview and opportunity to hear from professionals in the land use planning field. It was also a 1-credit course, so it could be a "light" add-on to a full course load.
I wanted a basic understanding of land use planning.
to hear from practitioners and to get background on urban development
To get more familiar with planning and land use issues.
Interest in Urban Planning
I took this course to get perspective on land use issues to inform my future academic pursuits.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely. The course and speakers also provided a myriad of contacts to pursue going forward.
Yes, the knowledge complemented assignments from other classes.
Yes - some speakers were stronger than others, but overall the class provided a good overview of the issue areas.
Yes

I expected to walk away with a deeper understanding of some principles of land use planning rather than the more qualitative aspects of the process. However, I enjoyed hearing about the challenges that people in the field are faced with daily.
No. I was hoping for a more basic course in land use planning and this assumed too much prior knowledge.
yes
No - see 17&18.
No, it was very, very basic. I have a vague understanding of some topics that are important in planning, but we did not delve in more deeply than naming them.
No, I think a lot more could have been done. The speakers were often uninteresting.
Yes.
Yes.
Somewhat
yes
Average.
Absolutely.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It is a terrific survey course which serves as an introduction to the relatively new and growing field of Land Use Planning.
If you are interested in planning in the northeast or are new to land use issues, then this is a worthwhile seminar course.
Good class, not much work, so well-worth the time.

I would suggest that students take this course only if land use is highly relevant to their field and that they have some background knowledge on the subject before taking this seminar, so they could focus more on the professional aspects of the course, such as networking with speakers and gaining a deeper understanding of job prospects and challenges.
make sure to do the readings before the seminar
Very limited in scope.
It's very basic, but take it if that's what you're looking for.
I don't think it is worth it unless you need another land use planning course on your transcripts. The three unit regional and local planning course is much better.

It is worthwhile, especially if you have no previous experience with land use planning or development. It is also helpful if you are interested in meeting land use practitioners from around the greater NYC/New Haven area.
make sure to talk to the speakers after their lectures
This is a great course and I found most lectures to be interesting if not useful. Worth the one hour per week.
